text:
No bio, just a name and headshot here. Links to author bio page. Analytics shows that nobody ever clicks the bio either.

Hot take: readers come for the content not the author.

_Unless_ you're a big name :wink:

text: Hi Mallory, if your clients are in the housing, credit or financial services categories, there’s a Google Ads issue (still happening but on their radar to resolve) that’s caused ads to serve much less often than usual. This is probably not related, but am mentioning it because the timelines match. Maybe more search results pages without ads boosted organic traffic in those industries...but maybe that could not account for 5x.

text:
Hi folks, I have a question! :slightly_smiling_face: Anyone here doing the relationship-based link building?

Do you only do it in SaaS, or do you think (or have experience) doing it in industries like health, cars etc? Do you think it's possible to collaborate with other companies in those niches and do link building based on relationships?

elements.text: Hi folks, I have a question!

Anyone here doing the relationship-based link building?

Do you only do it in SaaS, or do you think (or have experience) doing it in industries like health, cars etc? Do you think it's possible to collaborate with other companies in those niches and do link building based on relationships?

text: Hello! Not all of our members are guys. In an effort to be more conscious of the language we use to address each other, why not try “Hey, folks,” or “Hey everyone” instead?

I find it's hard to get the attention of people in other industries who aren't content marketers. I.e. if they publish healthcare posts but aren't doing it from a marketing POV, they don't get what I'm actually asking.

Warm relationships FTW!

text:
Hi all - I am looking for some advice on Lead Magnets for b2b selling to developers/data teams. I want to launch 1 (ideally 2) in April and from what I can tell there are several different formats these artifacts can take. :
• Apps (Hubspot Website Grader, <https://mode.com/roi-calculator/|Mode ROI calculator>, )
• Free Trial Sign Ups
• Whitepapers/ebook downloads 
• Free consultations 
• Checklists (...still haven't found a great example, but hubspot has some)
My question(s) are:
(1) Are there any other formats I am not thinking of? Preferably short form (i.e. not whitepaper or ebook)?
(2) Who typically crafts these? Content marketers? Writers? Developers?

attachments.title: ROI Calculator |  - Mode Analytics
attachments.text: See how much Mode can save for your organization
attachments.fallback: Mode Resources: ROI Calculator |  - Mode Analytics

text:
I think of gated offers as loosely falling into 6 buckets:
1. Educate, ex: courses, workshops, training, demos
2. Connect, ex: customer webinars, executive dinners / breakfasts
3. Gift, ex: food, swag
4. Advise, ex: whitepapers, ebooks, checklists
5. Product, ex: free tier, trial
6. Apps / tools
In my experience, most orgs are well positioned to create Educate offers (work with folks on your customer success team). Product offers will take buy-in from your product team. Gift offers are easy for marketing to run, but often low on differentiation. The world is packed with Advise offers, but good ones are still incredibly impactful. Apps / Tools are experimental. HubSpot's Website Grader still generates a meaningful percentage of their monthly leads, that's rare and you can't predict it, but it doesn't mean we shouldn't try!

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

elements.text: I think of gated offers as loosely falling into 6 buckets:
Educate, ex: courses, workshops, training, demos
Connect, ex: customer webinars, executive dinners / breakfasts
Gift, ex: food, swag
Advise, ex: whitepapers, ebooks, checklists
Product, ex: free tier, trial
Apps / tools

In my experience, most orgs are well positioned to create Educate offers (work with folks on your customer success team). Product offers will take buy-in from your product team. Gift offers are easy for marketing to run, but often low on differentiation. The world is packed with Advise offers, but good ones are still incredibly impactful. Apps / Tools are experimental. HubSpot's Website Grader still generates a meaningful percentage of their monthly leads, that's rare and you can't predict it, but it doesn't mean we shouldn't try!

text: <@UJG12DM1V> I love this list! One more thing I would add is the gated surprise and delight (for example a game). It's kind of a combo between 2 & 6, but can be surprisingly effective if you find something that resonates with your demo. Don't see a lot of this though, most likely because of the high risk involved

elements.text: I love this list! One more thing I would add is the gated surprise and delight (for example a game). text: It really depends on what you're going for. The main thing to consider is that portrait is traditional (thanks to regular books) and therefore what people expect/feel familiar with. Breaking from that is not a bad thing, but you should have a good reason -- examples include a data report where you need more horizonal space for charts or a target demo that is more used to landscape layouts/already bored of the norm. Invision did a great job of this in their maturity model report

elements.text: It really depends on what you're going for. The main thing to consider is that portrait is traditional (thanks to regular books) and therefore what people expect/feel familiar with. Breaking from that is not a bad thing, but you should have a good reason -- examples include a data report where you need more horizonal space for charts or a target demo that is more used to landscape layouts/already bored of the norm.
